properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Altona, Altona North, Derrimut, Laverton, Laverton North, Truganina
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Altona, Altona North, Derrimut, Laverton, Laverton North, Truganina.

  • There is a factory fire in Swann Drive, Derrimut. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
  • The fire is under control. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do:
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area:
  • You may see smoke.
  • Traffic in the area around the fire may be affected. 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Avoid contact with water at Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut Firewater has entered Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain due to an industrial fire at 118 Swann Drive, Derrimut. Avoid contact with the water (including pets) downstream of the fire location until further notice. Odours may be observed in the area. Avoid areas where odours occur. contact EPA Victoria for further information

This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 8:00 am 11 July 2024 or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility:

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  

If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Sanctuary Lakes, Laverton West, Seabrook, Point Cook
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Point Cook, Sanctuary Lakes, Laverton West, Seabrook.

  • There is a School Fire in Boardwalk Boulevard Point Cook
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is currently no threat to the community, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke or you live with someone who is sensitive to smoke, you should close windows and doors. Turn off heating and cooling systems.
  • To prevent the smell of smoke entering your home or business, close windows and doors.  
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services are on scene
  • Traffic in the area will be affected.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/07/2024 10:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Meredith and surrounds including Lethbridge, Bannockburn, Teesdale, Shelford, Inverleigh, Wingeel and Rokewood.
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on Friday 28 June.
  • An outbreak of High Pathogenicity H7N3 Avian Influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in poultry near Meredith. 
  • This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners.
Things you should know about avian influenza:
  • Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus.
  • To stop the spread of Avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined.
  • Movement controls are in place.
  • In Restricted and Control Areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit.
  • You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria Website.
  • Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat.
  • While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low.
All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick you should contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
What you should do:

If you own birds:
  • Bird owners in the Meredith Restricted and Control Areas should house all their poultry in cages or sheds.
  • Do not move your birds, eggs or equipment into, within or out of the Control or Restricted areas without a permit.
  • Bird owners should regularly check their birds and immediately report any unusual signs of disease to the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • Check the Agriculture Victoria website or phone 1800 226 226 for details on movement controls.   
To help prevent the spread of disease to your birds you should: 
  • Restrict contact between pet birds, poultry and wild birds. 
  • Prevent contamination of food and water by faeces or other animal waste. 
  • Keep equipment, yards and aviaries clean. 
  • Limit visitors to your birds. 
  • Bird owners should wash their hands before and after handling birds.
Check for signs of disease: 
Signs of the disease in birds may include:
  • Sudden death. 
  • Birds with difficulties breathing, such as coughing, sneezing, or rasping. 
  • Swelling and purple discolouration of the head, comb, wattles and neck. 
  • Rapid drop in eating, drinking and egg production. 
  • Ruffled feathers, dopiness, closed eyes. 
  • Diarrhoea.
  • Occasionally, nervous symptoms.
How avian influenza spreads: 
  • Avian influenza can be spread to other animals by movement of eggs, birds, people handling birds, vehicles and equipment between farms, and by clothing, footwear, aerosols, water, feed, litter, wild birds, biting insects and vermin.
Protecting your health: 
  • You can’t contract avian influenza by eating cooked chicken meat or cooked eggs.
  • Avian influenza does not usually infect people, but in rare cases, human infection can occur.
  • Most people are not at risk, unless they have contact with infected birds or animals, or their secretions, while in affected areas of the world.
This message was issued by Agriculture Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/07/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: COMMUNITY INFORMATION - ANIMAL DISEASE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Meredith and surrounds Issue Date: Friday 05 July 2024, 12:39 pm Next Update: Friday 12 July 2024, 06:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33725/moreinfo This Community Information message is being issued for Meredith and surrounds including Lethbridge, Bannockburn, Teesdale, Shelford, Inverleigh, Wingeel and Rokewood. - This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on Friday 28 June. - An outbreak of High Pathogenicity H7N3 Avian Influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in poultry near Meredith. - This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners. Things you should know about avian influenza: - Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus. - To stop the spread of Avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined. - Movement controls are in place. - In Restricted and Control Areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit. - You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria Website. - Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat. - While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low. All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick you should contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Terang and surrounds including Noorat and south-east of Mortlake. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued on Friday 28 June.
  • An outbreak of high pathogenicity H7N9 Avian Influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in poultry at Terang. 
  • This warning is relevant for all bird owners including poultry producers, bird keepers and pet bird owners.
Things you should know about avian influenza:
  • Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease that infects chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, guinea fowl, quail, pheasants and ostriches. Many species of wild birds, including waterfowl and seabirds can also carry the virus.
  • To stop the spread of avian influenza, the infected properties have been quarantined.
  • Movement controls are in place
  • In Restricted and Control areas, you cannot move birds, equipment and products within and out of the area without a permit.
  • You can find more information about movement controls, quarantine and permits and access an interactive map to search for your property on the Agriculture Victoria website.
  • Cooked eggs and cooked chicken meat are safe to eat.
  • While cases among humans in direct contact with animals infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses are possible, the current risk to the public remains low.
All bird owners should regularly check their birds. If you suspect your birds are sick, contact the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226.
What you should do:

If you own birds: 
  • Bird owners in the Terang Restricted and Control Areas should house all their poultry in cages or sheds.
  • Do not move your birds, eggs or equipment into, within or out of the Control or Restricted Areas without a permit.
  • Bird owners should regularly check their birds and immediately report any unusual signs of disease to the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • Check the Agriculture Victoria website or phone 1800 226 226 for details on movement controls.
To help prevent the spread of disease to your birds you should: 
  • Restrict contact between pet birds, poultry and wild birds. 
  • Prevent contamination of food and water by faeces or other animal waste. 
  • Keep equipment, yards and aviaries clean. 
  • Limit visitors to your birds. 
  • Bird owners should wash their hands before and after handling birds. 
Check for signs of disease: 
Signs of the disease in birds may include: 
  • Sudden death. 
  • Birds with difficulties breathing, such as coughing, sneezing, or rasping. 
  • Swelling and purple discolouration of the head, comb, wattles and neck. 
  • Rapid drop in eating, drinking and egg production. 
  • Ruffled feathers, dopiness, closed eyes. 
  • Diarrhoea. 
  • Occasionally, nervous symptoms. 
How avian influenza spreads: 
  • Avian influenza can be spread to other animals by movement of eggs, birds, people handling birds, vehicles and equipment between farms, and by clothing, footwear, aerosols, water, feed, litter, wild birds, biting insects and vermin.         
Protecting your health: 
  • You can’t contract avian influenza by eating cooked chicken meat or cooked eggs.
  • Avian influenza does not usually infect people, but in rare cases, human infection can occur.
  • Most people are not at risk, unless they have contact with infected birds or animals, or their secretions, while in affected areas of the world.
This message was issued by Agriculture Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/07/2024 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch & Act message is for Derrimut, Laverton North.

  • There is a fire in Swann Drive Derrimut involving a factory 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and act issued at 4:10pm
  • A wind change has caused the toxic smoke to be blown towards Boundary Road
Anyone located in in the watch and act warning area should close all windows and doors.
What you should do:
  • Close all exterior doors and windows. Close vents and ensure heating and cooling systems are turned off 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area:
  • Traffic in the area will be affected.
  • You will see smoke.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Avoid contact with water at Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain, Derrimut Firewater has entered Cherry Creek, Anderson’s Swamp and Kayes Drain due to an industrial fire at 118 Swann Drive, Derrimut. Avoid contact with the water (including pets) downstream of the fire location until further notice. Odours may be observed in the area. Avoid areas where odours occur. contact EPA Victoria for further information

This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

The next update is expected by 8:00am 11 July 2024 or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - INDUSTRIAL FIRE - Stay Indoors
Incident Location: Swann Dr, Derrimut
Issue Date: Wednesday 10 July 2024, 07:29 pm
Next Update: Thursday 11 July 2024, 08:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33745/moreinfo

This Watch & Act message is for Derrimut, Laverton North.

- There is a fire in Swann Drive Derrimut involving a factory 
- This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and act issued at 4:10pm
- A wind change has caused the toxic smoke to be blown towards Boundary Road


Anyone located in in the watch and act warning area should close all windows and doors.
